Let me point out for those of you who think funds are a good way to invest, what you are getting.

I have stocks in quite a few companies, you could call it my own fund. 100 shares here, 500 there, 1000 in some cases. Now, when I get the 10K form, which is the yearly report from those companies, the great majority of them show certain funds as having significant holdings. Among them are Black Rock, KKR, and Vanguard. So basically I have the same stocks they bought, and charge you to manage on a continuing basis. I bought them for $8.95, so a 100 share purchase cost me $.085 a share or less depending on how many I bought, and I only pay that fee once.

You can go to the companies websites look at their statement, and see who owns 5% or more of stock in the company. For instance, Berkshire Hathaway has 360,000,000 shares of Wells Fargo, and Buffett personally has 3,000,000 shares.

So you pay some fee to people who buy what you can buy, and they also get to profit with your money. But worse yet, even if the fund loses, they still get paid, and you can end up paying a capital gains tax if they sell, in order to give their holders money back.

Of course if a fund does not perform, people will go to another one, but that does not help those who lost with that fund. Worse yet, when the market falls, people panic and sell, so the fund sells to get cash to pay its investors.

Professor Krugman is absolutely correct in that austerity, won't only not solve the deficit, which is what the EU believes, it will actually make it worse. The solution to me seems to be that some form of debt relief, and even some stimulus additional debt is currently necessary. However, in the long run they should run a structural surplus or close to it at full employment ( in this case the 'natural rate" which includes both structural and frictional. The EU could hold on to some debt, forcing the Greeks to either reform their tax laws so evasion is less. If they fail then the EU could force them to pay of the debt with held. Some agreement that has stimulus not and a trigger to force reform seems to me the only way the two sided can reach an agreement.

Further, I have heard, that for some ridiculous reason the EU wants the burden increased taxes to fall on the Greek people, and not the rich, who apparently flaunt their tax evasion to the tune of billions.

It is quite amazing to see that Krugman feels inclined to write "who will ever trust Germany's good intentions after this?" Would he dare to write a sentence like this about any other western democracy.

What has happened? The German public as well as many politicians in Germany have come to the conclusion that Greece - if it stays in the eurozone - will turn into a state that will request and receive substantial subsidies over a long period of time. The German population (as well as that of many other eurozone countries) do not want to introduce such a system of permanent subsidies (it is also against the rules that all countries of the Eurozone have agree upon). So Schaeuble - presumably in accordance with many of the other Eurozone finance minsters - has offered Greece debt relief in exchange for Greece leaving the Euro. All Germany is doing here is to protect its taxpayers from future unforseeable risks. Germany has not started an illegal war like the US and the UK have done a decade ago leaving more than 10000 dead and destabilizing the middle east for years to come. All it is doing is try to keep its public finances manageable.

Krugman is a columnist writing an opinion. If you object to him raising the issue of trusting Germany, then surely you must object to Merkel saying she doesn't trust Greece. She has actual power and authority while Krugman just has a keyboard.

At 12, from the boy's perspective, the mother chose a new marriage and family over him. He was "allowed" back into his mother's life and then booted out again because--what a surprise--he was angry and probably violent/destructive.

A mother who wonders about how to balance the needs of her husband (the stepfather) vs her children is already in trouble. There should never be a balance; the child who predated the man should always come first.

Timo - you must be kidding. The U.S. financed the rebuilding of Europe after WWII. We sent our men and women to Europe during the Cold War to protect Europe from Soviet aggression. We championed the EU under the belief that shared prosperity would prevent more wars in Europe. We forgave massive amounts of debt, including German debt.

The question now is, is Europe for all Europeans or just for the Germans.

"Timo - you must be kidding. The U.S. financed the rebuilding of Europe after WWII. We sent our men and women to Europe during the Cold War to protect Europe from Soviet aggression."

The Allies first took all the German engineers and technology, right after the war. Then imposed harsh measures upon Germans, bringing Germany on the brink of starvation. Only the threat of Soviets changed all that in 1948. Who designed your Apollo rockets? The Germans.

The yearly occupation costs for Germany were about the same as the yearly Marshall aid. Americans definitely did not rebuild by themselves continental Europe.

During the Cold War, all western European countries had military conscription. We went to army because we had to. All capable men, tens of millions of us. We still have in Finland mandatory military service and we are not even part of NATO.

It was a mutual effort during the Cold War, nothing like the Americans like to think it was.

American defense spending is to the tune of about a Trillion Dollars per year, not the $100 Billion figure that you presented.

Department of Defense budget is greater than $600 Billion per year. The $600 Billion figure excludes expenditures are for maintining the nuclear weapons (funded through Dept of Energy) and Veterans Benefits which have a seperate budgets. Further, the $600 Billion excludes the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan which had seperate allocations. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States and http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/01/07/everything-ch...

So, yes, much of Europe is getting an (almost) free ride when it comes to defense expenditures. US should curtail its defense spending and focus on domestic priorities like other countries.

"I used to be about as pro-EU a Brit as you could find - mainly because what came before (centuries of blood and death) was so much worse - but even I am starting to question the whole edifice. If what should be, if not a minor issue, then certainly a technocratic side-issue about the necessity of fiscal transfers and moral hazard and similar dull-sounding jargon, can lead to this acrimonious omnishambles of nationalist name-calling and bickering, then what hope is there for the future of the union. The most depressing thing is how quickly people have fallen back on the old ethnonationalist stereotypes - the lazy, feckless southern Europeans versus the joyless, domineering northern Europeans - when they should know better than to go anywhere near that sort of language because of where it has lead us in the past. It feels like decades of work, so much more than just the Euro, but down to the very belief in the concept of greater prosperity through shared prosperity, is being frittered away for a few billion Euros. Back around 1990-1991, with the fall of the Soviet Union, I thought the proper response would have been a new Marshall Plan for all of the Eastern Block to get their decrepit infrastructure up to snuff and to protect those fledgling democracies from failing and to help bury any past animosities and hope for a form of European Community stretching all the way to the Bering Straight.

I did some research back then using things like Almanacs and real publications on economic statistics to get an idea of what a New Marshall plan might look like in 1990 dollars.

The original Marshall plan was about $16 billion. I figured in 1990 dollars that same level of aid would consist of $300 to $350 billion in 1990 dollars. Something the narrow minds of the Republican establishment would never accept. As a result, much of the Eastern block is a failure and Putin is a reaction to some of that failure.

But that $350 billion was in 1990 dollars. That was 25 years ago! No telling what those figures might be now, but a $500 billion doesn't sound unreasonable.

Seems like a lot of money but then we blew $3 trillion in Iraq and kept it off the books and didn't even sneeze over that. So imagine if we had spent one tenth of Iraq's money on healing the post cold war world? We would be living in a much better place - worth many times more than whatever was invested. But it takes courage and imagination to do that, and we are in an era where that is in short supply.
